utterances: That's a pretty hard thing to say I would think.

Yes, indeed it is because it really reduces them to three targets up there around the great lakes and the big ten football states that they're still going after- Minnesota, which hasn't voted Republican for president since Richard Nixon in 1972.

Wisconsin, which has been in the Democratic column since 1988 or rather that was the last time it was in the Republican column - oh no, excuse me, it has been in the Democratic column since 1988, and Pennsylvania which has gone Democratic the last four times running.
Those are the three, they're still going after up in that Great Lakes tier.
One other item.
There has been some polling since the vice presidential debate last night.
Undecided voters say, they liked Joe Biden's performance.
Is any of this really going to matter 32 days from now?
Probably not given that the preponderance of polling seems to show that people thought Joe Biden did a better job in the debate overall or if you will, won the debate.
Now, of course, everyone's been commenting on Sarah Palin's performance which was better than expected.
But, it doesn't seem to be making a big game changer kind of difference because people in the end preferred Biden as vice president.
NPR senior Washington editor Ron Elving with us from Washington again and following that debate and the vote to come on the House floor.
Ron, thanks.
Thank you, Alex.

When Elaine Fydrych in New Jersey passed way at the age of 63, her obituary included the request, quote, ""in lieu of flowers, please do not vote for Hillary Clinton."" And this from the obit of Joseph Vogt of Virginia - when he died at the age of 64, quote, ""Joe also loved the Republican Party.
God bless him, as this will thankfully be one less vote for Donald Trump in the presidential election.
Seems that this year, more Americans are making their electoral preferences known from the hereafter.
Katie Falzone is vice president for operations at Legacy.com.
They host obituaries for newspapers and funeral homes.
She joins us now from the studios of WBEZ in Chicago, where, of course, deceased Americans can always vote.
Thanks very much for being with us, Ms. Falzone.
Thank you, Scott.
Thank you.
First though, back to the presidential campaign and the battle over Democratic superdelegates.
One of the most prominent of them, Congressman John Lewis of Georgia, officially switched yesterday from Hillary Clinton to Barack Obama.
And in Texas, which votes on Tuesday, another superdelegate, State Representative Senfronia Thompson, also made the same jump on the same day; from Clinton to Obama.
And all 35 superdelegates will come from Texas.
Two of them are coming from the same household.
DAY TO DAY'S Alex Cohen spent some time with that couple in Austin.
Betty and Boyd Richie are the kind of couple who look like they should be together.
They're both short, with bright eyes and big warm Texan smiles.
The two first met in Wichita Falls just along the Oklahoma border.
We met when we were in high school.
And his mother and my sister arranged a blind date.
A few years later, says Boyd, came the night when they just happened to walk by a jewelry store.
(Superdelegate): And we looked in the window and she said that was the ring that she liked and I told her I thought she ought to have it and that we out to get married.
The Richie's have been married for 42 years now.
And many of those years have been spent in politics.
In 1976, Boyd ran for district attorney and won.
He says he was influenced by his dad, who worked on the campaigns of several Texas democrats.
I was a newspaper carrier at about ten years of age.
And my dad thought that would be a good way for him to disseminate printed material about his candidate.
So he gathered up a bunch of friends of mine who also had paper routes, and paid us I'm sure all of a dollar a day probably, to go out on Saturdays and hand people campaign literature.
And who was gonna turn down these cute little ten-year-old kids?
Those campaign skills wound up coming in handy.
Two years ago, Boyd was unanimously elected as chair of the Texas Democratic Party.
Betty Richie has also run for office as a state representative eight years ago, an experience that gives her empathy for what Hillary Clinton is going through now.
It's very difficult, in my opinion, for a woman to be elected in a man's world.
When I was running, people would look at Boyd and say, how can you let her and allow her to run?
She needs to be in your home.
Betty didn't win that election, but she remained very active in the Texas Democratic Party, which is how she wound up becoming a superdelegate.
This will be both her and Boyd's first time serving as superdelegates in a presidential election.
As of yet they haven't pledged themselves to either campaign.
Betty says she finds likeable qualities in both candidates.
She has charm and she's strong, smart.
Obama, wow.
He's bringing so much excitement to young people.
You know, both of them are just wonderful.
So how do you choose?
That's a difficult question.
I don't know yet, I really don't.
Betty and Boyd Richie have heard arguments in favor of both candidates, from friends, family members; they even had the chance to meet personally with Barack Obama.
Boyd says the candidate didn't treat him any differently, despite his superdelegate status, and for that he was grateful.
I'm not sure that superdelegate is an accurate term.
We don't have super powers.
I can't run faster than a speeding bullet or leap over tall buildings, particularly as vertically challenged as I am, in a single bound.
They both say their superdelegate votes should represent what Texans want, not just what they want.
I feel strongly about that, I really do.
I'm not just in this for myself.
I was elected by the people from Texas.
Betty says she plans on talking with voters.
In this election season, that might mean checking in with a lot of Texans.
There has already been record-breaking turnout in early voting.
For example, in Travis County, where the state capitol is located and where I met the Richie's, about 3,700 registered Democrats voted early in 2004.
So far this year more than 53,000 have already voted.
Alex Cohen, NPR News.
You know this is the season for the people who make an art out of analyzing presidential candidates, but at Slate.com, Emily Yoffe is making a science of it, or a quasi-science anyway.

Emily has taken a series of psychological tests on behalf of the three leading candidates - that would be Senators Clinton and Obama, and Senator McCain - to reveal, well - Emily Yoffe, welcome back from Slate.com.
To reveal what?
Their basic personality types and what we can expect.
Let me just add here that we have links at our Web site, NPR.org, to your piece, which in turn has links to explain this psychological test.
It's called Myers-Briggs.
It splits people out into, I think, 16 different kinds of categories and they refer to all of them.
And your headline for this piece at Slate.com is ""The Supervisor, the Champion, and the Promoter"".
So who's who?
Who is the supervisor?
No question, Hillary Clinton.
She's an EFTJ.
Let me translate that really quickly.
Extroverted, concrete thinking, tough minded, loves schedules.
This is the kind of person who likes to drill down in details, makes organizations run.
The world can't exist without them, and they like to remind you of that.
OK, Senator Clinton is the supervisor.
How about the champion?
That's Barack Obama.
Some psychologists divide these 16 types into four groups.
His overarching type is - no surprise: the idealist.
Senator Obama is a champion, an ENFP.
Extrovert, intuitive, a feeling person, and also doesn't like to be ties to schedules.
This type have tongues of silver, very much believe in the power of words.
They tend to be leaders of movements, not politicians.
Martin Luther King, Jr. is one of the best known idealists.
You write that these people very seldom wind up in executive positions.
They seldom wind up anywhere because there aren't that many of them; only about 2 percent of the population are in this category.
Whereas about 30 percent of people who are executives or managers would fit Senator Clinton's profile.
That's right.
We all know many more people who are good at details, get the paperwork done, than we do people who give you a thrill up your leg, as Chris Matthews says about Barack Obama.
Yes, that's correct.
That criticism didn't stop Gervais.

I was very, very moved and gratified when you made the announcement two months ago, well before you had a chance to review ""Little Fockers.

The TV show ""Glee"" won three awards, one of which went to Chris Colfer for best supporting actor.

Most importantly, to all the amazing kids that watch our show and the kids that our show celebrates, who are constantly told no by people in their environments, by bullies at school, that they can't be who they are or have what they want because of who they are, well, screw that, kids.
